On 19 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, police forces clashed with the (Kraze Barye Gang) Vitelhomme Gang (supported by the Grand-Ravine Gang) in the Thomassin neighbourhood as they attacked Laboule, Metivier, and Peguy-Ville neighborhoods, among others. Overnight, gunshots were heard along the Corlette Road, Delmas 95, and Pernier. The morning after, dead bodies were found between the Panamerican Avenue and Corlette Road. It is unknown if there were civilians among the deceased. At least five bodies were found. Another two bodies of gang members were found after having been lynched and burned by Bwa Kale Movement (coded separately). One body had been crushed by a vehicle. At least 5 fatalities.
On 19 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces killed a gang leader in Savane Pistache neighbourhood. 1 fatality.

On 19 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, armed residents identified as members of the Bwa Kale movement lynched at least two gang members of the Kraze Barye Gang (Vitelhomme Gang) and Grand-Ravine Gang. The lynching occurred amid clashes between police officers and gang members as they attacked Thomassin, Laboule, Metivier, and Peguy-Ville neighborhoods, among others (coded separately). At least 2 fatalities.

On 18 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped a journalist and former spokesperson of ancient President Martelly at his residence, in the Vivy Mitchell neighbourhood. The abductors broke into the house through the back of the property. They contacted the victim's family. He was released on 21 March under unknown circumstances.

On 18 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police and military forces, together with private security guards, shot and killed at least three gang members as they intervened to repeal an attack against the Bank of the Republic of Haiti, located on Pavee street (Bicentenaire). At least one police officer was shot and injured during the clash. Another version stated that there were four fatalities among the gangsters and two injured among security forces. At least 3 fatalities, at least 1 injured.

On 18 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they attacked residents, private properties, and companies' facilities in Laboule, Thomassin, Boutilliers, and Pelerin neighborhoods. Around a dozen people were killed and several were injured. One fatal victim was a woman described as the head of Women's Classical School. A bank branch, a gas station, and several houses were attacked and looted, including that of a judge at the Superior Court of Auditors and Administrative Litigation, who had been evacuated before the attack (in Laboule 18). In Laboule 12, gunshots were heard as the gangsters stole some vehicles. The criminals had arrived in three vehicles. Other versions stated that they used four trucks and 27 motorcycles. At least 12 fatalities, several injured.

On 17 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, overnight, armed gang members on motorcycles opened fire on civilians on the Panamerican Avenue (likely around Petion Ville - Juvenat) , killing more than 10 people (up to 15 according to other sources) (drive-by). Their corpses were found scattered on the streets in the morning of 18 March. One was found inside a pick-up truck vehicle. At least two of the victims were identified as vendors. One deceased was killed while sleeping. Also, a body was found in Juvenat neighborhood, causing a roadblock. At least 10 fatalities

Around 16 March 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unspecified number of Kenyan police forces were killed as they took part in a reconnaissance mission announced on 14 March as previous step before the deployment of the Multilateral Support Security Mission (MMSS) (coded separately). The information was reported by a Kenyan judge but it is yet to be confirmed by national authorities. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 15 March 2024, between Delmas and Petionville (coded to Port-au-Prince - Petionville), Ouest, members of several socio-political organizations held a march to decry the interference of the CARICOM and the international community in Haiti's internal affairs. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones. The march had initiated on the Delmas Road. It had been called by the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party and the National Awakening for the Sovereignty of Haiti movement.

On 15 March 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a gang member in the Berquin neighbourhood. The deceased was identified as a member of the Base 5 Secondes Gang. The operation was carried out by the Nippes police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin. 1 fatality.

On 15 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members in Bas Delmas. Some gangsters were killed, although there is no information on a specific number. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 15 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, overnight, police forces shot and killed several members of the G-9 Gang during clashes in Delmas 6 (Cite Numero Un neighbourhood) and Delmas 8 (2eme Cite Saint Martin neighbourhood). Clashes took place amidst a security operation aiming at removing a roadblock erected by the G-9 Gang in Delmas 6 around 11 March (coded separately). Clashes continued until the early morning of the following day. Several firearms were seized. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 15 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, police forces clashed with unidentified armed men, answering an attack against the National Police Academy (Academie neighbourhood). Casualties unknown.

On 14 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang kidnapped a US citizen (described as a well-known youtuber) and a Haitian man. The abduction took place as the US citizen flew to Port-au-Prince to interview the G-9 Gang leader. The abductors demanded a ransom of 600,000 USD for their release. On 30 March, the US youtuber and the Haitian man were released after 40,000 dollars were paid.
On 14 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, police forces on a patrol shot and killed two men in the Drouillard neighbourhood. Motivation unknown. 2 fatalities.

On 14 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, in the morning, gang members fired shots against the Toussaint Louverture International Airport, forcing airport employees to run away (Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood). The attack occurred when workers were trying to repair the fence that gangs previously breached. As the gang members fired shots in the area, a police officer was injured by a stray bullet. He was the courtyard of police headquarters, near the airport. 1 injured.

On 14 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, overnight, gang members attacked the Vivy Mitchell, Belvil, and Bellevue neighborhoods. A number of families took to the streets to take refuge elsewhere. Casualties unknown.

On 13 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, overnight, the Vitelhomme Gang attacked residents and clashed with police forces in the vicinity of the Police National Academy (Academie neighbourhood) and in the Vivy Mitchell neighbourhood. Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.
On 13 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, armed individuals riding a motorcycle shot and killed a BSAP police agent in Laboule neighbourhood (drive-by). 1 fatality.

On 13 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, gang members attacked the Torcelle neighbourhood. Gunshots were heard there and near the Toussaint Louverture International Airport, in Mais Gate/Clercine 2. Casualties unknown.

On 12 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, residents and gang members held a demonstration over unspecified claims a day after Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, announced his resignation and that of his government (coded separately). During the demonstration, barricades of burning tires were set up and a drugstore was set on fire.

On 12 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, people demonstrated in Delmas 32. They erected burning tires in different areas such as Delmas 30, Delmas 21 (Delmas 19/Mackandal), and Delmas road. There is no information on the motives of the demonstration.

On 11 March 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, people demonstrated in Barriere Bouteille area. The demonstrators threw stones and bottles, although no target was specified. There is no information on the motives of the demonstration.

On 11 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, gang members opened fire on the National Police Academy. The shooting took place as the graduation ceremony of the 33rd police promotion was being held at the Academy. Casualties unknown.
On 9 March 2024, in Ganthier, Ouest, gang members attacked a police station and took control of the area. Casualties unknown.

On 9 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, police forces clashed with gang members as they tried to expel the criminals from the vicinity of the National Palace (Champs de Mars), which had been attacked the day before (coded separately). During clashes, at least a woman was shot and injured by a stray bullet, and a journalist was hit and wounded by a police tear gas canister. At least 2 injured.

On 9 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces intervened the premises of the Social Welfare and Research Institute (IBSR) (public institution), in Turgeau neighbourhood, and forced a group of displaced residents who had taken refuge there to leave the building. During the police intervention, a 14-year-old boy was killed. In Bourdon neighbourhood, police forces chased displaced population taking refuge at the Citizen Protection Office (OPC), forcing them to leave. 1 fatality.
On 8 March 2024, in Ganthier, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang killed at least 11 civilians as they attacked residential areas in the commune. At least 11 fatalities.
On 8 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang opened fire and looted the city hall. The scene was recorded on video. Casualties unknown.
On 8 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, armed men attacked the Calvaire sub-police station in unreported circumstances. Casualties unknown.

On 8 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, police forces clashed with members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) as they attacked the National Palace and three police stations in Champs de Mars. Several gang members and people (unspecified affiliation) were killed. An unknown number of police officers were killed and injured. The criminals set fire to several vehicles at the Ministry of the Interior and Territorial Communities (Champs de Mars), although the police intervention prevented the burning of the building. In Bas Peu de Choses, the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training (MENFP) was looted. Gunshots were heard in Turgeau, Poste Marchand, Pacot, Lalue, Canape-Vert, and Nazon. The attack on the National Palace was part of coordinated attacks by the G-9 Gang leader and the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
On 7 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members set fire to a store in the down town. Casualties unknown.

On 7 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they attacked police and state facilities in the down town. Several gang members were killed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 7 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gangs set fire to residents' houses in Delmas 3 and 5 (in Delmas 5 neighbourhood). The Public Company for the Promotion of Social Housing (EPPLS) and the Dadaou Sport Centre, both located in Delmas 3, were also looted and burned. An UNIBANK branch was looted in Delmas 18 (located in Cite Numero Un neighbourhood). Casualties unknown.

On 7 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, several dozens of citizens, called by the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party, held a demonstration along the Delmas Road demanding the departure of Prime Minister Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires in different areas. Police forces intervened using tear gas near the Canada Embassy (Delmas 75 neighborhood). Another report also indicates that gunshots were fired in the area as well as in Delmas 3 (in Delmas 5 neighbourhood).

On 7 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, citizens held a demonstration in the Juvenat neighbourhood demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up roadblocks. A group of motorcycle drivers gathered to ask for the barricade to be removed. Burning tires were also erected in Faubert and Villate streets (Centre Ville (Ouest) neighbourhood). A rara group was also registered between Faubert and Rigaud streets (Centre Ville (Ouest) too).

On 6 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, police and military forces clashed with armed group members in Delmas 28. During clashes, the armed individuals set fire to several vehicles. Casualties unknown.

On 6 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, gang members fired shots against the Toussaint Louverture International Airport (Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood) and clashed with police forces in the area. Casualties unknown.
On 6 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members attacked the so called Cafeteria police station in the Portail Saint Joseph neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

On 5 March 2024, in Frecineau, Artibonite, dozens of armed men, described as affiliates of the Jean-Denis Gang, opened fire on residents following an altercation between two individuals over the funeral of a voodoo priest's relative. At least four people were injured. Two others were arrested and beaten up. Witnesses claimed that the armed men entered a hospital with their heavy weapons. The gangsters established a curfew in the village. At least 4 injured.

On 5 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, unidentified gangs looted several banks. They took one of the banks' safe and kidnapped the security guards after seizing their weapons. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 5 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a military officer was shot and killed by a stray bullet while he was at a police office near the National Palace, in Champs de Mars. Authorship unknown. 1 fatality.

On 5 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members attacked and looted the Higher National Institute for Midwifery Training, on the Monseigneur Guilloux street (Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood). Solar panels and vehicles were stolen. Casualties unknown.

On 5 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, gang members fired shots against the Toussaint Louverture International Airport (Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood). Overnight, armed clashes were mentioned between the gangsters and police forces. Casualties unknown.

On 5 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, armed members of the Vitelhomme gang opened fire and vandalized the National Police Academy, located on the Freres Road (in Academie neighbourhood). Police forces intervened and repelled the attack. Casualties unknown.

On 5 March 2024, near Thomazeau, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped three nuns at the residence of the Congregation of Sisters of St. Joseph of Cluny, in the Morne a Cabrits peaks. The victims were released on 6 March under unspecified circumstances.

On 4 March 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, for the second consecutive day, in the morning, several opposition militants of the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party held a demonstration in front of the Cap-Haitien International Airport demanding that the flight of Prime Minister Ariel Henry not be hosted. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires in several neighborhoods.

On 4 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang clashed with members of the Chien Mechant Gang in Duval and Cite Doudoune neighborhoods. During clashes, a branch of the BNC bank was looted. Clashes between these gangs were also reported in Santo (coded separately) and Marassa (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 4 March 2024, in Belladere, Centre, in the morning, a mob of residents lynched the leader of the Salami Gang. 1 fatality.

On 4 March 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang clashed with members of the Chien Mechant Gang. During clashes, armed members of the population were present in the Carrefour Marassa area, where several vendors were stripped and some motorcycles were stolen (authorship unspecified). Clashes between these gangs were also reported in several neighborhoods in Croix-des-Bouquets (coded separately) and in Santo (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 4 March 2024, in Santo, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang clashed with members of the Chien Mechant Gang. Clashes between these gangs were also reported in several neighborhoods in Croix-des-Bouquets (coded separately) and in Marassa (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 4 March 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, citizens held an anti-government demonstration, asking for the resignation of Prime Minister Ariel Henry, and set up roadblocks on the Route Nationale #7 near the Antoine Simon Airport. Demonstrators occupied the airport runway and set fire to a plane.

On 4 March 2024, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, overnight, hundreds of prisoners rioted at the Civil Prison as part of an escape attempt. During the riot, male prisoners raped several women prisoners. Police guards intervened with tear gas and gunshots were heard. Three inmates were killed and at least four others were injured. 3 fatalities, at least 4 injured.

On 4 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, armed gang members opened fire on a national police convoy in the Bizoton neighbourhood. There were several injured (affiliation unspecified). There were no fatalities.

On 4 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gang members aligned to the Living Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm gang) set fire to a police station in the Carrefour Aeroport neighbourhood. Several vehicles were burned. Policemen who were inside were forced to abandon the building. Police officers coming from Solino tried to expel the criminals, although they did not succeed. Residents living nearby fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

On 4 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, gang members fired shots against the Toussaint Louverture International Airport and tried to occupy the airport's runway entering the compound through a hole in the airport's wall. Police and military forces deployed to reinforce security clashed with the gangsters, who aimed at preventing Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, from landing and returning to Haiti. The gang members were expelled. Moments later, the gang members set fire to a police checkpoint that had been installed to access the airport. Gunshots were heard in the Guy Malary Terminal, the National Police General Direction, and the Central Judicial Police Direction (Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood). Gang members vandalized the MSC Plus company offices (HT Monquette neighbourhood). Casualties unknown.

On 3 March 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, several opposition militants of the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party held a demonstration in the vicinity of the Cap-Haitien International Airport demanding that the flight of Prime Minister Ariel Henry not be hosted. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires in several neighborhoods.

On 3 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, overnight, unidentified armed individuals stormed the Delmas 33 police station (Hatt Thomas neighborhood), forcing six policemen who were inside to abandon the building. 21 arrested individuals managed to escape. Casualties unknown.

On 3 March 2024, in Cabaret, Ouest, gang members clashed with police forces as they attacked and set fire to the Cabaret police station. Several people were shot and injured (affiliation unspecified). Several injured.

On 3 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members set fire to the Poste Marchand police station, in Lalue neighbourhood. The police officers who were inside fled the premises. Casualties unknown.
On 2 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gang members occupied and set fire to the Calvaire police station. Casualties unknown.

On 2 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, gang members fired shots against the Toussaint Louverture International Airport, in Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood. An aircraft belonging to the Sunrise Airways Company was damaged by the bullets. Overnight, gunshots were heard in the Carrefour Fleuriot neighbourhood as some videos showed several gang members coming back to their strongholds after having escaped from the Civil Prison, assaulted by other gangs earlier that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 2 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, gang members aligned to the Living Together gang-led initiative (aka Viv Ansanm gang) set fire to a police station in the Cazeau neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

On 2 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, overnight, the 400 Mawozo Gang assaulted the Civil Prison and released thousands of inmates. As police forces intervened and clashed with the gangsters, an unspecified number of police officers, penitentiary staff members, and prisoners were killed and injured. A prison officer was shot in the stomach. The jail's assault was part of coordinated attacks against the two major Haiti prisons led by the G-9 Gang with the support of gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). A nearby police station, the Croix-des-Bouquets Peace Court, a funeral company, and several vehicles were set on fire. Three bank branches were looted and two security guards were kidnapped. Their whereabouts are unknown. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 2 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang fired shots against the National Palace (Champs de Mars) and assaulted the Civil Prison (a.k.a. National Penitentiary), in Centre Ville neighbourhood. Police forces clashed with the gangsters in the vicinity and within the prison, resulting in at least 30 fatalities among police officers, penitentiary staff members, and prisoners. The corpses of the deceased were found around the prison and scattered in several nearby areas of the downtown. Some had gunshot wounds, some other were mutilated, burned, or tied up. An unknown number of prison workers and inmates were injured. Thousands of prisoners fled. Some imprisoned gangsters were released by their accomplices, while other inmates took the opportunity to escape. Around 90 prisoners decided to stay inside the prison when police forces left the building. They were described as the convicted in relation to the killing of President Jovenel Moise (coded separately). The gang members had spied on the facilities with a drone since 29 February. The prison's assault was part of coordinated attacks against the two major Haiti prisons led by the G-9 Gang with the support of gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). Still that day, the Ministry of Culture and Communications (Bois Verna neighbourhood) was occupied and looted. Gunshots were heard in Champs de Mars, Lalue, Bas Delmas and Poste Marchand. The building hosting Radio TV Caraibes was hit by stray bullets (Morne a Tuf). A young woman was shot in the mouth as she took refuge at the FASCH Faculty (Avenue Christophe neighbourhood). At least 30 fatalities, several injured.
On 1 March 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, gang members attacked a police station. Police forces intervened and repeal the attack. There were no casualties.

On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they intervened to expel the criminals from the Civil Prison (a.k.a. National Penitentiary). Clashes were also reported near the National Port Authority (APN) facilities (La Saline), in Champs de Mars, and on Saint-Honore street (Morne a Tuf neighbourhood). At least one fatality was counted (affiliation unknown). Gunshots were heard in different areas, such as Bicentenaire, Enterrement Street, Reunion Street, Grand Rue, Mgr Guilloux Street, and Bas Delmas. This was the second consecutive day of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). At least 1 fatality.

On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) set fire to a police station in Delmas 3 (Delmas 5). Gunshots were heard in Simon Pele. Another report indicates that the gunshots might have been aimed at vehicles. Gunshots were also registered in Carrefour Drouillard and Delmas 24, as well as the Airport Road, among other areas. This was the second consecutive day of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader with the support of gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. Between 29 February and 1 March, at least 33 people were received in La Paix Hospital (Cite Saint-Georges) due to gunshot wounds caused amidst clashes between the police and the gangsters. At least 33 injured split across two events.

On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, several dozens of citizens held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Another report indicates that barricades of burning tires in Delmas 40B, 48, and 75, which might possibly related to the demonstration.

On 1 March 2024, between Delmas and Tabarre (coded to Port-au-Prince - Tabarre), Ouest, dozens of police officers on motorcycles marched along the Delmas Road and demonstrated in front of the Police General Direction, in the Clercine neighbourhood, to demand the recovery of the corpses of those officers who were killed by gang members the day before in Bon Repos (coded separately). They also decried the lack of proper equipment at work. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones.

On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Drouillard. A report indicates that some passersby were wounded in the area. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots. Casualties unknown.

On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped a Catholic priest at the Saint Anne parish (Morne a Tuf). He was released later that same day. It was not clarified if a ransom was paid for the release.

On 29 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, residents held a demonstration against Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires on Marion street. The mobilization occurred after it was known that the PM plans to stay in power until 2026.

On 29 February 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, gangs members attacked civilians in La Plaine du Cul-de-Sac areas. At least two civilians were killed and two others were injured. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. At least 2 fatalities.

On 29 February 2024, in Carrefour Zaboca, Grande-Anse, residents held a demonstration against Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 7. The mobilization occurred after it was known that the PM plans to stay in power until 2026. Demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe, a former convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti.

On 29 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 Gang members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) attacked the Ministry of the Agriculture and occupied the Agronomy and Veterinary Medicine Faculty (UEH University), in Damiens neighbourhood. Students were taken as hostages. One student was shot and injured in the ear, while a young girl was grazed by a bullet. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. 1 injured.

On 29 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) clashed with police forces on the Airport Road and near the Bernard Mevs Hospital (Village Solidarite neighbourhood). At least six civilians (two women) were injured by the bullets. Gunshots were heard in Pele Simon neighbourhood. Between 29 February and 1 March, at least 33 people were received in La Paix Hospital (Delmas - Kernizan) due to gunshot wounds. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. At least 33 injured split across two events.

On 29 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, gang members shot and injured a police officer as they attacked the Toussaint Louverture International Airport and the Guy Malary Terminal, in Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood. At least one airport worker was injured by the bullets. Passengers were seen jumping to the ground to avoid being shot. Three aircrafts and several facilities were hit by the gunshots. Flights were suspended. Gunshots were heard in Clercine, on the 15 Octobre Boulevard, and near the US Embassy. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. At least 2 injured.

On 29 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) clashed with police forces as they set fire to several houses in Saint-Honore Street (Morne a Tuf), and they burned the Portail Leogane police station. One source stated that the building was empty when the arson attack took place. A different version stated that some officers were inside, although they were not injured. Gunshots were heard in Bicentenaire, Carrefour-Feuilles, Bel Air, Bas Delmas, Post Marchand, Champs de Mars, and Morne a Tuf areas. The gangsters occupied the Sylvio Castor National Stadium (Morne a Tuf) and kidnapped an employee. His whereabouts are unknown. An Education Centre on Allerte Street was vandalized while two trader women were killed on the Magloire Amboise Avenue (Bas Peu de Choses). At least 25 people injured by the bullets were received in the Haiti State University Hospital (Morne a Tuf). Two of the wounded died. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. At least 4 fatalities, at least 23 injured.

On 29 February 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, the Canaan Gang, together with the Chien Mechant Gang, killed at least five police officers (three men and two women) and injured five others during an attack against a police station. One of the wounded was lynched to death by the gangsters. The bodies of the deceased were tortured and mutilated. One was taken by the criminals and another corpse belonging to a police inspector was found the day after. The police station and a patrol vehicle were set on fire. The gangsters took over the police station and, on March 11, published a video showing a police officer held hostage. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya in a government visit. At least 6 fatalities.

On 29 February 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) attacked the National Old Age Insurance Office (ONA) in the Shada neighbourhood. No further details on the event were mentioned. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks against public institutions led by the G-9 Gang leader and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. Casualties unknown.
On 28 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, the Vitelhomme Gang attacked residents in the commune. The details on the attack were not reported. Casualties unknown.

On 28 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, the Vitelhomme gang attacked the National Police Academy (Academie neighbourhood) with heavy machinery and broke a section of the institution's wall. As police forces responded, two gangsters were killed. Gunshots were heard in Pernier and on the Frere Road. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. 2 fatalities.
On 28 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members on the Magasin de l'Etat street. During clashes, a woman was shot and injured in the face. 1 injured.

On 28 February 2024, near Gilbert, Artibonite, police forces shot and killed a gang member during a clash in the Granfon village. The deceased was the right hand of the Salami Gang leader. Seven gangsters were arrested, including a woman. A quantity of ammunition and firearms were seized. 1 fatality.

On 27 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, police forces clashed with members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) in the down town. Between 26 and 27 February, at least 20 people were shot and injured as a result of clashes between the police and the gang members. At least 20 injured split across two armed clashes coded by ACLED in central Port-au-Prince.

On 26 February 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, in the morning, moto taxi drivers affiliated to the Drivers and Owners of Motorcycle Taxis of the Artibonite Trade Union held a demonstration on the National Road 1 demanding the release of their President, who was arrested the week prior for insults and defamation against a judge. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires near Carrefour Turene.

On 26 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals kidnapped a trader woman as she was working on the Monseigneur Guilloux street (Morne a Tuf neighbourhood). There is no information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. Her whereabouts are unknown.

On 26 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces shot and killed at least four members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) during clashes in Fort St. Claire area (Morne a Tuf neighbourhood). Their corpses were burned by residents (coded separately). The gang members had set fire to some houses on the Saint-Honore street and gunshots were heard in Portail Leogane sector and in Chareron, Reunion, and Joseph Janvier streets (Morne a Tuf). Between 26 and 27 February, at least 20 people were shot and injured as a result of clashes between the police and the gang members. 4 fatalities and at least 20 injured split across two armed clashes coded by ACLED in central Port-au-Prince.

On 26 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a mob of residents set fire to the corpses of four gang members who had been killed amidst clashes with police forces moments before in areas of Portail Leogane and Morne a Tuf neighborhoods (coded separately). The deceased were affiliates of the Base 5 Secondes Gang.
On 25 February 2024, in Grand Boucan, Centre, an unknown number of armed men shot and killed two civilian passengers as they attacked a public transport vehicle in Fonds Cheval area. 2 fatalities.

On 25 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, supporters of several socio-political organizations held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister Ariel Henry. Burning tires were registered in Delmas 34 and 65. Demonstrators, who were called by the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party (PPD), decried the international community's interference in Haitian political affairs.

On 25 February 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a gang member. The deceased was described as a gangster from Mariani (Carrefour commune). This was part of a police operation led by the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernest Muscadin. 1 fatality.

On 25 February 2024, in Mariani, Ouest, the leader of the Bout Ba Gang killed a police officer on the National Road 2 and burned his body. One source stated that the attacker tore off the victim's head and ate part of his body. The same source stated that both the perpetrator and the victim had a mutual past and that the motivation for the attack could be personal animosity between them.1 fatality.

On 24 February 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang beat up a woman and shot and killed her son. According to residents, the gang members interrogated the woman, asking for the whereabouts of a man and as she claimed to ignore it, the gangsters beat her up. When her son arrived and verbally confronted the gangsters for the beating, the criminals took him to the vicinity of a river and shot and killed him. His corpse was moved to the morgue although the gangsters stole it and threw it into the river. 1 fatality.

On 24 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in the vicinity of the Salomon Market (Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood) and in Portail Leogane sector. An unspecified number of victims were reported (not clarified if wounded or killed). Casualties unknown.

On 23 February 2024, near Toutier, Centre, armed members of the population shot and killed a local leader of the Canaan Gang who used to operate on the National Road 9. The killing took place while he was at a voodoo ceremony, in the Crete Brulee communal section. The perpetrators were supporting police forces in the fight of gangsters in the Mirebalais commune. 1 fatality.
On 23 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, police forces clashed with unidentified armed men near the US Embassy. The police fired tear gas and real bullets. Casualties unknown.

On 23 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped six Brothers of the Sacred Heart Congregation and a teacher near the Jean XXIII School (Catholic Christian Group), in Morne a Tuf neighbourhood. The abductors asked for a ransom as a condition for their release. Another Catholic priest was abducted near Notre Dame de Fatima Chapel (Portail Saint Joseph neighbourhood). On the same day, up to 10 people were kidnapped in the capital, including two cameramen from Tele Amen (Christian media outlet). Around 9 March 2024, the mentioned teacher and four Brothers of the Sacred Heart Congregation were released. The other two religious Brothers were released on 26 March under unknown circumstances.

On 23 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of the Grand-Ravine Gang set fire to several civilian properties on Cameau street (Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood). Some residents fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

On 22 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, a mob of residents lynched three gang members who had killed a police officer and several civilians in Mahotiere 85 earlier that day (coded separately). Other reports suggest that the number of lynched gang members was higher. At least 3 fatalities.

On 22 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, overnight, gang members carried out several attacks, killing at least six people. One of the victims was a police officer who was shot by three armed gang members and his body was mutilated and set it on fire, in Mahotiere 85 (Terrain Ti Carme neighbourhood). A civilian riding a motorcycle was decapitated on the road. An unspecified number of other residents were killed. As part of the attacks, gang members looted a hotel in Brochette neighbourhood. The perpetrators were later lynched by a mob of residents (coded separately). At least 6 fatalities.

On 21 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, employees of the National Solid Waste Management Services (SNGRS) held a demonstration over labor demands and asking for the payment of due salaries. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires in front of the institution's facilities (Petite Place Cazeau neighborhood).

On 21 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of the Belair Gang shot and killed two civilians and injured several others as they attacked residents in the Fort National neighbourhood. This was part of a gang offensive aiming at taking control of the neighbourhood. 2 fatalities, several injured.

Around 21 February 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals abducted several transport drivers and passengers in Portail Leogane sector. There is no information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. Their whereabouts are unknown.

On 20 February 2024, in Terre Rouge, Centre, police forces shot and killed two gang members and several accomplices during a security operation in Terre Rouge and nearby Fonds Cheval area (Grand Boucan). An unknown number of gangsters were injured. The deceased were described as the leader of the Ti Avion Gang (a branch of the Canaan Gang) and his brother. Two women were arrested. One was the gang leader's wife. Firearms and vehicles were seized. At least 2 fatalities, several injured.

On 19 February 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, an man, armed with a machete, hit and injured a tele-radio journalist as he was returning from work. The attack was described as an assassination attempt. 1 injured.

On 19 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, a demonstration was held and roadblock with burning tires were set in Delmas 30 and Delmas 33. Trucks were also used to block roads in Delmas 19 and 21. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

On 19 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, residents held a demonstration in the Fort National neighbourhood against rumors stating the transfer of agents of the Departmental Operation and Intervention Brigade (BOID) assigned to this community. Demonstrators set up barricades (nature unknown) and gunshots were heard during the mobilization. Residents claimed that the agents' presence persuades gang attacks. The rumors were later denied.

On 19 February 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, police forces shot and killed two gang members during a clash in the commune. It happened during a police operation that was carried out a day after gang members attacked a police station in Terre Rouge (coded separately). 2 fatalities.

On 19 February 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, an unknown number of gang members on motorcycles shot and killed a police officer and injured his wife as they opened fire on the vehicle they were travelling with their son in the Petite Anse neighbourhood (drive-by). The officer shot and killed a gangster before succumbing to his injuries. The minor escaped unharmed. The attack took place when the victims were returning from a commercial bank. Several gangsters were arrested for his involvement in the shooting. 2 fatalities, 1 injured.
On 18 February 2024, near Toutier, Centre, gang members attacked areas in the Crete Brulee communal section. No further details were mentioned. Casualties unknown.

Around 18 February 2024 (as reported), near Gimballe, Centre, gang members beat up and abducted an unknown number of drivers as they hijacked goods trucks in Morne Blanc. Their whereabouts are unknown. Casualties unknown.
On 18 February 2024, in Grand Boucan, Centre, gang members attacked several areas in the commune. No further details were mentioned. Casualties unknown.

Around 18 February 2024 (as reported), in Carries, Ouest, rival armed men engaged in armed clashes as part of a fight for territory. Dozen of vehicles got struck as a consequence of armed clashes. Casualties unknown.

On 18 February 2024, near Thomazeau, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang opened fire on a public transport minibus near the Morne a Cabrits peak. The driver and nine passengers were killed. Eight others were injured. The vehicle was doing the Mirebalais/Port-au-Prince route when the shooting took place. The attack was carried out near a police station as policemen were trying to expel the criminals from the National Road 3, although no interaction between the officers and the gangsters was mentioned. 10 fatalities, 8 injured.

On 18 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, overnight, an unknown number of armed individuals shot and killed four people in the Bouc-Champagne area. Their corpses were found in the morning of 19 February. Perpetrators and motivation are unknown. 4 fatalities.

On 18 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, an explosive device was activated in the house where the Catholic Christian Bishop of Anse-a-Veau/Miragoane was being hosted, in Peguy-Ville neighbourhood. The bishop got injured and burned. The attack was described as an assassination attempt. Perpetrators and motivation are unknown. 1 injured.

On 18 February 2024, in Terre Rouge, Centre, overnight, gang members attacked and took control of a police station, forcing the police officers who were inside to flee. The gangsters also attacked police officers nearby Fonds Cheval area. Casualties unknown.
On 18 February 2024, in Dieudon, Ouest, armed gang members shot and injured a police officer on his back as they opened fire on a police patrol in the Duval area. 1 injured.

On 17 February 2024, in Liancourt, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang attacked drivers and trucks drivers on the roadway. At least two passengers of a vehicle were killed. Three merchants' trucks were set on fire, although the occupants escaped unharmed. Several other people were burned alive. One source described the deceased as smugglers who used to facilitate access to dangerous areas, although this was not confirmed by other reports and their affiliation was not clarified. A fourth vehicle crashed on the road while the driver was trying to flee from the attackers. At least 2 fatalities.

On 17 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, overnight, an unknown number of armed individuals on motorcycles opened fire indiscriminately as they rode through the commune (drive-by). A boy who was at a house was shot and injured by a stray bullet. At least 1 injured.

On 17 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, people demonstrated in Delmas 33. They erected burning tires and marched towards Gerald Bataille (near Zone Predailler/Charbonnie). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the demonstration, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

Around 17 February 2024 (between 15 - 19 February), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members abducted a man in the Bicentenaire neighbourhood. The victim was a teacher at the Faculty of Law and Economic Sciences. His whereabouts are unknown.
On 16 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, members of the Bwa Kale Movement militia killed 10 gang members from Martissant. 10 fatalities.

On 15 February 2024, in Tiburon, Sud, overnight, police forces killed two gang members operating in Tiburon. A woman who was also killed. Another version of the event suggest that the gang members were lynched by armed residents. 3 fatalities.

On 14 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals shot and injured a police officer on the Oswald Durand Street. The victim was transported to hospital by several citizens. He died while undergoing treatment. 1 fatality.

On 14 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unknown number of armed men in a moving vehicle shot and killed more than five people in the Portail Leogane neighbourhood (drive-by). There was a photographer among the fatal victims. Motivation unknown. At least 5 fatalities.

On 13 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, people held a demonstration in Delmas 48 which was dispersed, though there is no further information on the responsible and the circumstances of the intervention (coded A2 as Police forces). Burning tires were registered in Delmas 32. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the demonstration, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

On 13 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, clashes were registered in Cazeau. Gunshots were also registered in Butte Boyer and Croix-des-Missions. There is no information on the circumstances or people involved in the clashes.

On 13 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang attacked the National Penitenciary, wounding at least four people in Du Centre Street (Centre Ville neighborhood). The police reacted and managed to arrest one gang member. At least 4 injured.

On 13 February 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, overnight, two police agents of the Departmental Law Enforcement Unit (UDMO) beat up and injured the government commissioner at the Cap-Haitien Court of First Instance during a traffic incident on the street. As the policemen asked the commissioner to move his vehicle (improperly parked), and he refused to obey, the officers attacked him. The police version stated that the commissioner tried to slap one of the officers. The commissioner was moved to hospital, where he stayed for at least four days. 1 injured.

On 12 February 2024, near Marin, Ouest, gang members from the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang clashed with the rival gang led by Ti Gabriel. Another version states that the clash was between members of the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang. During clashes, residents were attacked and hundreds of houses were burned in La Plaine du Cul-du-Sac area. Some young women were raped in front of their parents. Thousands of civilians fled their homes. This was part of a gang war for territory and for the control of economic activity in the targeted areas. According to one source, more than 20 people were killed amidst gang clashes near Marin and in Sibert. At least 20 bodies were found burned in the Marie Madeleine zone. According to another report, on 12 February more than 30 civilians were killed amidst gang clashes in Carrefour and La Plaine du Cul-du-Sac. At least 20 fatalities split across two events. 10 fatalities coded for this event.

On 12 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, in the morning, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in the commune. During clashes, the gangsters attacked and killed residents and set fire to hundreds of houses. Some young women were raped in front of their parents. Thousands of civilians fled their homes. On 12 February, more than 30 civilians were killed amidst gang clashes in Carrefour and La Plaine du Cul-du-Sac. At least 30 fatalities split across three events. 10 events coded for this event.

On 12 February 2024, in Sibert, Ouest, gang members from the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang clashed with the rival gang led by Ti Gabriel. Another version states that the clash was between members of the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang. This was part of a gang war for territory and for the control of economic activity in the targeted areas. Some residents fled their homes. More than 20 people were killed amidst gang clashes near Marin and in Sibert. At least 20 bodies were found burned in the Marie Madeleine zone. At least 20 fatalities split across two events. 10 fatalities coded for this event.

On 12 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, gang members from the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang clashed with the rival gang led by Ti Gabriel in Terre Noire, Barye Fe, and Blanchard neighborhoods. Another version states that the clash was between members of the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang. This was part of a gang war for territory and for the control of economic activity in the targeted areas. Some residents fled their homes. More than 15 people were killed and an unknown number were injured as a result of gang clashes in Terre Noire, Blanchard, and Duvivier neighborhoods (Tabarre) (coded separately). At least 15 fatalities split across two events.

On 12 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, people demonstrated. They marched from Delmas 30 towards Carrefour Aeroport. Demonstrators threw stones at cars and burning tires were erected. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the demonstration, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

Around 12 February 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, gang members from the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang clashed with the rival gang led by Ti Gabriel in Duvivier neighbourhood. Another version states that the clash was between members of the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang. This was part of a gang war for territory and for the control of economic activity in the targeted areas. Some residents fled their homes. More than 15 people were killed and an unknown number were injured as a result of gang clashes in Duvivier, Terre Noire (Cite Soleil), and Blanchard neighborhoods (Cite Soleil) (coded separately). At least 15 fatalities split across two events.

On 12 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members from the Bel Air neighbourhood opened fire in the vicinity of a carnival parade being held in Champs de Mars. Several people participating in the parade were injured by the stray bullets. Gunshots were also heard in Bel Air neighbourhood. On the same day, a medical center was evacuated as an exchange of fire took place nearby. The perpetrators were not clarified. Several injured.

On 12 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, armed civilians and members of a communal militia from the 'Do Karyann' community burned to death a former local elected official from the Carrefour 10th municipal section whom they accused of being a gang informant. The attack took place after suspected messages were found on his phone. The attack was described as a case of vigilante justice. 1 fatality.

Around 11 February 2024 (weekend of), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members shot and killed at least two children as they tried to flee from gang-controlled areas in the downtown. It was not clarified if this happened amidst clashes between rival gangs. At least 2 fatalities.

On 10 February 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, members of the Chien Mechant Gang engaged in armed clashes with rival gangsters from the Terre Noire Gang on the National Road 1 and in La Plaine du Cul-du-Sac area. The clashes lasted for several days. An unknown number of civilians were killed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Around 10 February 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in Terre Noire and Blanchard neighborhoods. At least six casualties were counted among civilians in Blanchard (unspecified if they were injured or killed). The Rhum Barbancourt S.A. Company announced the closure of its facilities after the burning of eight hectares of cane fields near the company's premises as a result of the gang clashes. Clashes lasted for several days. Gunshots were heard in Waaf Jeremie area. Casualties unknown.

On 9 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, members of a gang operating in Maceline (Bizoton neighbourhood) lynched a voodoo priest inside his residence and killed his daughter as she tried to intervene and prevent her father's death. 2 fatalities.

On 9 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, gang members from Mariani attacked residents in the Riviere Froide area (section 11). Gunshots were heard in the area. Some families fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

Around 9 February 2024 (between 5 - 14 February), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood. During clashes, residents were attacked and an unknown number of people fled the area and took refuge elsewhere. According to the sources, the clashes have been ongoing several days during the week, although the exact days are not specified. The clashes prevented the circulation of trucks and the work of custom officers and has also contributed to fuel scarcity. Casualties unknown.

On 8 February 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, people held a demonstration and erected barricades of burning tires in Alternative Crossroad in the downtown area. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricades, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 8 February 2024, in Grand-Goave, Ouest, people held a demonstration and erected barricades of burning tires. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks and barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 8 February 2024, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, overnight, people held a demonstration and erected barricades of burning tires. During the mobilization, rioters looted and set fire to a First Instance Court. They also tried to burn the house of a government commissioner, although they did not success. Stones were thrown against the property of a doctor, causing material damages. This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

Around 8 February 2024 (between 5 - 11 February), in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, gang members attacked residents in the commune. An unknown number of people fled the area and took refuge elsewhere. Casualties unknown.

On 8 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, members of unidentified gangs clashed. There is no information on the circumstances of the clash. Also, a roadblock was set up on the Route Nationale #1 in Damiens while gunshots were heard in Sarthe and Terre Noire. Casualties unknown.

On 8 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators barricaded the Delmas Road with burning tires. Police forces used tear gas to disperse the crowd. During the police intervention, a journalist covering the event was shot and injured by a rubber bullet in Delmas 38 (Delmas 17 neighborhood). His lost an eye. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 injured.

On 8 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, clashes were registered in the areas of Champs de Mars, Fort National, and Sans Fil Street. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the clashes. Also, bags and empty vehicles were used to erect barricades on Canape-Vert road. Barricades were also registered in Bois Verna near Berne street. There is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up. Casualties unknown.

On 7 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the fourth consecutive day, thousands of government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires and looted the Grande-Anse Civil Protection warehouse. They also threw stones and pieces of bottles against private residences in Nan Site, among other neighborhoods. Pro-government supporters who opposed the mobilization opened fire on the crowd, shooting and injuring more than 10 demonstrators and journalists. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). At least 10 injured.

On 7 February 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the third consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6. Several public institutions were looted and set on fire, like the Croix-Rouge Peace Court and the Ouanaminthe City Hall. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, thousands of residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Three journalists who were covering the mobilization were beaten up by rioters participating in the demonstration. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, for the third consecutive day, government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Gros-Morne, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang operating in the Tibwadom neighbourhood opened fire on a police station. There were no police officers in the building at the moment of the shooting, as it had been abandoned by the officers. A radio journalist was shot and injured in his testicles during the attack. It is unknown if the journalist was targeted intentionally. On 9 February, the police took the control of the building. 1 injured.

On 7 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, hundreds of government opponents and members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade police (BSAP) held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires and looted several businesses. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them. At least one demonstrator was injured. Tens of demonstrators on motorcycles rode to the PM residence (in Musseau). The demonstration, which was called by the PPD Party, was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). One source stated that he was seen among the crowd. At least 1 injured.

On 7 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, police forces shot and killed five members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade police (BSAP) and arrested three others in Laboule neighbourhood. The circumstances around the incident were not clarified. A first version stated that, as a group of armed BSAP agents moving in a vehicle ignored a police halt, an armed clash erupted. A second version supported that the police officers engaged in a conversation with the BSAP agents before opening fire on them. The head of the Synapoha police union claimed that the BSAP agents opened fire after police the asked them to drop their weapons, prompting officers to shoot. On the contrary, the Haitian Military Association claimed that the BSAP agents were ambushed and they did to resist. A closed person to Guy Philipe (former rebel who called on anti-government demonstrations) claimed that the shooting was an assassination attempt against Philipe, as the police believed that he was travelling inside the BSAP vehicle. The BSAP vehicle was seized and the five corpses were buried in a common grave in Petionville cemetery. An investigation was ordered. A Petionville interim executive police officer and his brother-in-law were said to be involved in the killings. Since 29 January, the BSAP police are banned from circulation with arms. 5 fatalities.
On 7 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, police forces shot and killed three gang members during a clash on the Freres Road. Several firearms were seized. 3 fatalities.

On 7 February 2024, in Hinche, Centre, for the third consecutive day, dozens of government opponents, called by the EDE Party, held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters threw stones and looted the departmental office of the Economy and Finance Ministry and the City Hall. Some items were stolen. Police forces intervened with tear gas and arrested several individuals. Another group of rioters, armed with knives and machetes, entered the Communal Market and burned tires. Gunshots were heard through the day. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, for the fourth consecutive day, residents, members of the Committed to Development Party (EDE), and partisans of the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party (PPD) held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. The crowd was integrated by masked individuals armed with machetes and riding motorcycles. Rioters tried to loot a warehouse, although police forces intervened with tear gas and prevented it. One demonstrator was stabbed and injured (perpetrator unknown). Also, roadblocks were set roadblocks were set on the Route Nationale #2 in Bergeau, Charpentier, and on the Route Nationale #7 up to the Saint Simon Airport near Vernet. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 injured.

On 7 February 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, for the second consecutive day, thousands of government opponents and members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade police (BSAP), called by the EDE Party, held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades (nature unspecified), and threw stones against a police patrol and against the National Old Age Insurance regional office (ONA). ONA security guards fired shots against the crowd, although no casualties were mentioned. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, for the third consecutive day, thousands of government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters threw stones and looted several private companies. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them. During the police intervention, two journalists were physically aggressed by agents of the Anti-Narcotics Brigade and got their equipment damaged. According to a report, the journalists were accused by the police of making the population hostile towards them and favoring their sympathy with the BSAP. The demonstration, which was joined by many supporters of the Platform Pitit Desalin Party, was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, for the third consecutive day, government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. During the mobilization, rioters burned tires and set fire to three buildings, one of them being the departmental office of the Planning and External Cooperation Ministry and the Peace Court. Two vehicles from the institution were calcined. They also looted a food warehouse belonging to a police officer. In response, police forces fired tear gas to disperse them. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, thousands of residents and members of socio-political organizations held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. During the mobilization, some vehicles were burned and police forces intervened to disperse the rioters. A 18-year-old woman was shot and killed by the police as the crowd marched towards Frecyneau police station. Several other demonstrators were injured. This part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 fatality, several injured.

On 7 February 2024, in Terrier Rouge, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. As a group of rioters attacked a police station, police officers intervened using tear gas and firing into the air to disperse them. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 6 February 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, for the second consecutive day, thousands of citizens and supporters of the EDE party held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Armed individuals from Raboto looted and vandalized the Peace Court and the Counter-Third Party Vehicle Insurance Office (OAVCT), among other public institutions. Some items were robbed. Police forces were present, although no intervention on their side was mentioned. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 6 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the third consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 7. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 6 February 2024, Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals opened fire on the vehicle where the leader of the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party was travelling in. He escaped unharmed, although his driver was shot and injured. This happened as an anti-government mobilization called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti) was being held in the commune. 1 injured.

On 6 February 2024, between Delmas, Port-au-Prince, and Petionville (coded to Port-au-Prince - Petionville), Ouest, for the third consecutive day, hundreds of citizens (some of them armed with machetes), agents from the Protected Areas Security Brigade police (BSAP), and supporters of the National Awakening for the Sovereignty of Haiti movement held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires. In Bourdon (Port-au-Prince), police forces fired tear gas. At least one demonstrator was injured. When the crowd reached Petionville, rioters looted the Tiger gas station and gunshots were heard in the Juvenat neighbourhood. In the Saint-Pierre square, the presence of Guy Philippe (leader of the National Awakening for the Sovereignty of Haiti movement, and a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on a revolution in Haiti) attracted hundreds of supporters (up to 600 according to one source). At least 1 injured.

On 6 February 2024, in Hinche, Centre, for the second consecutive day, hundreds of government opponents and members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police, called by the Committed to Development Party (EDE) and the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party (PPD), held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters threw stones, tried to set fire to the city hall, and burned several motorcycles. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them. At least one demonstrator was shot and injured (likely during the police intervention). The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). At least 1 injured.

On 6 February 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, government opponents and members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade police (BSAP) held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. During the mobilization, police forces clashed with BSAP agents, resulting in one demonstrator killed and four others injured. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 fatality, 4 injured.

On 6 February 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the second consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. During the mobilization, heavily armed individuals fired shots in all directions and attacked a police station. Several people were injured by the bullets (affiliation unknown). In response, police forces intervened shot and killed a suspected perpetrator. A group of masked rioters vandalized the city hall and set fire to several vehicles belonging to the institution. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 fatality, several injured.

On 6 February 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, for the second consecutive day, thousands of residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires, threw stones, and clashed with police forces, who fired tear gas against the crowd. Gunshots were heard (authorship unspecified). The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6. Public institutions remained closed. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Terrier Rouge, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Trou-du-Nord, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6. Public institutions remained closed. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, near Morpeau, Ouest, government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires in the Lizon neighbourhood.
