The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). It was supported by the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police, although their presence was not mentioned.
On 5 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, members of at least three gangs aligned to the G-Pep La Gang attacked positions of the rival G-9 Gang in the commune. Casualties unknown.

On 5 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, armed gang members attacked residents in Ti Sous (near Clocher), La Grenade, and Sapotille neighborhoods, among others. According to witnesses, at least two civilians were killed (a resident and a moto taxi driver). Several others were injured. The gangsters were said to be based in Mariani. Some families fled their homes. At least 2 fatalities, several injured.

On 5 February 2024, between Delmas, and Port-au-Prince (coded to Port-au-Prince - Delmas), Ouest, for the second consecutive day, dozens of government opponents, called by the Committed to Development Party (EDE), held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Barricades of burning tires were set up in Champ de Mars, Lalue, Canape-Vert, and Bourdon. Unidentified individuals spilled oil along the road leading to Delmas 32. Gunshots were heard in La Saline, Lalue, Bel Air, Nazon, Christ-Roi, and Solino. When the crowd reached Petionville, a sit-in was held in front of the PM's residence, in Delmas 60. Police forces fired tear gas, hitting the EDE party leader who was among the crowd. At least five demonstrators were injured. The PM was escorted and transferred to another location. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by the Anti-Corruption Union Brigade (coded separately). At least 5 injured.

On 5 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, members of the Vitelhomme gang entered the government office for vehicles assurance (OAVCT), located on Mais Gate Avenue (Chateau Blond neighbourhood). They looted the place and kidnapped people from the premises. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 5 February 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, several hundreds of residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. They accused him of being involved in the killing of former President, Jovenel Moise, and asked for justice. They also opposed the Natcom and Digitel companies and described them as accomplices of PM. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones. Police forces intervened (methods unspecified) and dispersed the crowd. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Hinche, Centre, residents and armed members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. They set up a roadblock on the Celimene Louverture street, where rioters were seen throwing stones and pieces of bottles. They also looted a customs office. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). It was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by the Anti-Corruption Union Brigade (coded separately). Another report indicates that gunshots were heard and possibly related to the presence of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP), although it is not clear if it was directly related to the demonstration.

On 5 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, for the second consecutive day, thousands of government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. On the National Road 7, rioters set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones against police forces, who responded firing real bullets and tear gas. A demonstrator was shot and killed, while at least three others were injured. Demonstrators marched through the streets with the corpse of the deceased demonstrator. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by the Committed to Development Party (EDE), the Platfom Pitit Desalin party (PPD) party, and Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 fatality, at least 3 injured.

On 5 February 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, hundreds of militants from the Platform Pitit Desalin Party (PPD) and members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police held a demonstration with banners demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6. The demonstration was called by the PPD party in the context of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the second consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the 'Nan Site' Road, among others. A vehicle belonging to a civil employee of the police was set on fire. Police forces intervened using tear gas to disperse the crowd. Gunshots from tear gas were heard on the Source-Dommage street, among others. The Communal Market and several public institutions remained closed. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters burned tires and erected barricades on Simonds Avenue. They also set fire to the National Directorate of Drinking Water and Sanitation office (DINEPA) and two vehicles belonging to the institution. Police forces intervened and shot and injured two demonstrators. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 2 injured.

On 4 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. They set up barricades of burning tires on several roads. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 4 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, hundreds of government opponents called by the Committed to Development Party (EDE) and the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party (PPD) held a march with banners demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. The march, which had initiated in Carrefour Aeroport (Delmas) and in Champs de Mars (Port-au-Prince), ended in Musseau (Delmas). In Musseau, rioters tried to set fire to carnival stands and a sit-in was staged in front of the PM's residence. A dozen police forces intervened using tear gas and dispersed it. The mobilization was attended by the PPD party leader (hit by the tear gas), several representatives of the EDE party, and unionist leaders.

On 4 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, hundreds of residents participating in pre-carnival activities held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They shouted anti-government slogans and spoke out against police forces and the departmental delegate. Police forces used tear gas and dispersed them. Clashes between both sides were mentioned. Overnight, rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the Mackandal Street. This happened in the context of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 2 February 2024, in Bassin Bleu, Nord-Ouest, armed group members from Tibwadom kidnapped the Bassin Bleu mayor and several other people. The armed individuals looted the mayor's house and then released him. The other victims remained captive. Their whereabouts are unknown.

On 1 February 2024, in Trou-du-Nord, Nord-Est, a group of young men who identified themselves as members of the FMT, some of them armed with firearms, gathered on the Route 6 shooting into the air and throwing bottles and stones against people who attempted to demonstrate against the government. The action sought to prevent demonstrations to demand the departure of Prime Minister Ariel Henry called by local organizations. There were no fatalities.

On 1 February 2024, in Hinche, Hinche, in the morning, armed members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police and several socio-political organizations held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Herny. The BSAP agents also opposed the government's decision to ban them from circulating with fire weapons and the BSAP's uniform. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires in the vicinity of several public institutions. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

Around 1 February 2024 (as reported), in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Herny. On the Source-Dommage street, rioters set up barricades of burning tires and police forces intervened using tear gas to disperse them. Some elderly people, pregnant women, and kids fainted due to tear gas (not clarified if they were taking part in the demonstration). This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 31 January 2024, off the Coast of Mariani, Ouest, members of the Bout Ba Gang abducted 70 passengers (including children and a baby) from a vessel that was carrying merchandise. The victims were released on 6 February 2024.

On 31 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, citizens and political militants held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters burned tires. On 31 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, rival gang members clashed in the Pernier neighbourhood. The gangsters were likely to be members of the 400 Mawozo Gang against affiliates of the Vitelhomme Gang (a.k.a. Kraze Barye Gang), who had clashed in the area the day before (coded separately). Between 30 and 31 January, a dozen civilians were killed and an unknown number were injured by the gangsters. Some residents fled their homes, while others were prevented to do it by the gangsters, who fired into the air. Police forces intervened and forced the gangsters to withdraw. At least 10 fatalities split across two events.

On 31 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in several neighborhoods, including Lalue area. During clashes, a stray bullet entered the premises of the Sainte Rose de Lima school, although no one was injured. The institution suspended its activity after this. Casualties unknown.

On 31 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, hundreds of citizens of several socio-political organizations held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires. Police forces intervened using tear gas and dispersed the crowd at the height of Delmas 73 and Delmas 60. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 30 January 2024, in Santo, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang engaged in armed clashes with members of the Vitelhomme Gang (a.k.a. Kraze Barye Gang). Several civilians were killed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 30 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, members of the G-9 Gang engaged in armed clashes with rival gangsters affiliated to the G-Pep La Gang in Drouillard area. Dozens people were killed. Several dozen families fled their homes to take refuge elsewhere. At least 12 fatalities.

On 30 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang engaged in armed clashes with members of the Vitelhomme Gang (a.k.a. Kraze Barye Gang) in Pernier and Freres neighborhoods. Only in Pernier, at least four people were killed. Between 30 and 31 January, a dozen civilians were killed and an unknown number were injured by the gangsters. Among the wounded, there was a man who was shot while picking up his son from school. Several hundred residents left their homes and took refuge elsewhere. At least 10 fatalities split across two events, at least 1 injured.

On 30 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the fourth consecutive day, gang members from different factions of the G-9 alliance that operate in La Saline and Wharf Jeremie clashed in La Saline neighbourhood and nearby areas as part of a fight for territory and for the control of passage fees imposed on trucks leaving Varreux Oil Terminal. The gangsters were described as members of the Base Nan Chabon Gang (led by Marc) who had engaged in an internal plot against their leader, other reports suggest that members of Base Nan Tokyo and Base Krache Dief participated in clash (all affiliated with the G-9). Between 27 and 30 January, more than 20 fatalities were counted among the gang members. At least 9 civilians were killed, and more than 30 were injured as a result of clashes between gangsters from Wharf Jeremie and La Saline. At least 29 fatalities and 30 injured split across four related armed clash events coded between 27 and 30 January.

On 29 January 2024, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Commercial and school activities were paralyzed. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately).

The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately). 2 fatalities.

On 24 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the third consecutive day, several hundreds of residents, supported by members of the Surveillance Brigade for Protected Areas (BSAP) police, held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. The BSAP members fired shots in all directions on the National Road 6 as they tried to intimidate business owners. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). The BSAP members also demonstrated against the ANAP former director's revocation by a government decree the day prior.
On 24 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces shot and killed a gang member during a clash near Champs de Mars. A firearm was seized. 1 fatality.

On 22 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. On 21 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, police forces clashed with gang members and gunshots were heard in Bizoton, Lamentin, and Diquini neighbourhoods. The report also indicates that people threw bottles and rocks at passers-by. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the incidents, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 17 January 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 17 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the fourth consecutive day, members of the Belair Gang attacked the Solino neighbourhood as they clashed with rival gang members. The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 20 fatalities split across five events. At least 7 injured split across five events.

On 17 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, unidentified gang members attacked residents on the Laraque street and its surrounding areas. Tens of families got trapped at their houses as the attack took place. Casualties unknown.

On 17 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, an unknown number of people were kidnapped near the OAVCT. Armed individuals were also seen in the area. The report indicates that the victims might have been taken to the Truitier area in Carrefour. Although there is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the kidnapping, latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 16 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, the Belair Gang, supported by the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) attacked the Solino neighbourhood and close areas (Carrefour Pean, Delmas 18, and Delmas 24) as they clashed with rival gang members. The gangsters, who aimed at taking control of the public markets, chased residents and set fire to several houses. At least a person was killed and several were injured. Police forces intervened and expelled the criminals (coded separately). An unknown number of residents fled their homes. The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 20 fatalities split across five events. At least 7 injured split across five events.

On 16 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the tenth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 16 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces clashed with members of the Belair Gang as they intervened to expel the criminals from the Solino neighbourhood and several nearby areas which had been the target of an armed offensive in the last days (coded separately). During clashes, an unknown number of gangsters were killed. Unspecified fatalities coded as 3.

On 16 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the second consecutive day, residents and members of the Surveillance Brigade for Protected Areas (BSAP) police held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators, who claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), set up barricades of burning tires. Some of them were armed with firearms and machetes. Unidentified individuals threw stones against the BSAP agents. Between the 15th and the 18th of January, one person was killed during the demonstrations against the Prime Minister. 1 fatality split over four events.

On 16 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gang members set fire to residents' houses in Delmas 18 (Cite Numero Un neighbourhood), killing an unspecified number of civilians. Gunshots were heard also heard in Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighborhoods). Residents were fleeing the area. People had already fled their homes towards Delmas after their communities were attacked by the Belair Gang on several occasions in the last days (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 15 January 2024, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, citizens held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires. Demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 15 January 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, citizens held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires. Demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 15 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, members of the Belair Gang clashed with rival gang members in the Solino and Carrefour Pean neighbourhoods. During clashes, Belair gangsters set fire to several houses. Some residents fled and took refuge elsewhere. The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 20 fatalities split across five events. At least 7 injured split across five events.
Around 15 January 2024 (month of), in Mariani, Ouest, members of the Bout Ba Gang abducted dozens civilians on the National Road 2. The whereabouts of the victims remain unknown.

Around 15 January 2024 (month of), in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang clashed with members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) in the Nan Remy village. Casualties unknown.

Around 15 January 2024 (month of), in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, a group of armed gang members raped a 17-year-old girl several times and shot and killed her as she was on her way to school through a road outside the Brooklyn neighbourhood. 1 fatality.

Around 15 January 2024 (month of), in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) clashed in their stronghold, in Tabarre 70 (Torcelle neighbourhood), over internal disputes. Up to 63 gang members were killed. At least 63 fatalities.

On 15 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the ninth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood and in nearby Waaf Jeremie neighbourhood, in the Cite Soleil commune(coded separately) as part of a fight for territory. At least five people were killed in the crossfire. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. According to one of the sources, the gang members involved in the clashes were from the Grand-Ravine Gang, Base Project La Saline Gang, and the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang), against the Micanord Gang (a.k.a. Whart Jeremie Gang). At least 5 fatalities split across two events.

On 15 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, several hundreds of residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the Airport road, among others, and threw stones against the house of a former senator whom they accused of supporting the repression of demonstrators. Clashes were mentioned between the rioters and security guards from the former senator's private residence. Police forces intervened (methods unspecified) and restored order. Public and private institutions kept their doors closed during the mobilization. Demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 15 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, residents and members of the Surveillance Brigade for Protected Areas (BSAP) police held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They burned tires and used containers and trucks to set up roadblocks. Some of them were seen with pointed weapons and gunshots were heard (authorship unknown). Access to several public institutions was blocked, including the Peace Court. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). Police forces were present, although no intervention on their side was mentioned. Between the 15th and the 18th of January, one person was killed during the demonstrations against the Prime Minister. 1 fatality split over four events.

On 15 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in Waaf Jeremie neighbourhood and in nearby La Saline neighbourhood, in the Port-au-Prince commune (coded separately) as part of a fight for territory. At least five people were killed in the crossfire. According to one of the sources, the gang members involved in the clashes were from the Grand-Ravine Gang, Base Project La Saline Gang, and the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang), against the Micanord Gang (a.k.a. Whart Jeremie Gang). At least 5 fatalities split across two events.
On 14 January 2024, in Montrouis, Artibonite, a mob of residents decapitated a gangster. The attack was described as vigilante violence. 1 fatality.

On 14 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the Belair Gang attacked the Solino neighbourhood as they clashed with rival gang members. Several residents were injured by the bullets. Police forces intervened (methods unspecified) and expelled the criminals from the area. The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 20 fatalities split across five events. At least 7 injured split across five events.

On 14 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the eighth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.
On 14 January 2024, in Saint-Michel-de-l'Atalaye, Artibonite, an unknown number of armed men attacked a police station (methods unspecified), allowing several inmates to escape. Casualties unknown.

On 13 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the seventh consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 13 January 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, gang members from the Williamson locality killed over 10 people in the area. The report indicates that the gangsters believed that the victims had provided support to a rival armed group. At least 10 fatalities.

On 13 January 2024, near Gros-Morne, Artibonite, gang members kidnapped 45 passengers from a bus belonging to the Patrick Tours company, in the Tibwadom village. Among the victims, there was a rapper artist, who was later released. A ransom of 1 million was demanded as a condition for the release of each abducted victim. The whereabouts of the rest are unknown.

On 12 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the sixth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 12 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the second consecutive day, hundreds of residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators, who were joined by moto taxi drivers and members of the Surveillance Brigade for Protected Areas (BSAP) police, set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones against the house of a former senator. The demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).
On 12 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed individuals clashed with soldiers in Champ-de-Mars. There is no information on the circumstances of the clash. Casualties unknown.

On 11 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members kidnapped a peace judge of the Carrefour commune court. The abduction took place as the victim got off a bus in the Martissant neighbourhood. He was liberated on 15 January after the payment of a ransom. It is known that kidnappers had demanded 500,000 USD.

On 11 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the fifth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.
On 11 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped a doctor on the Reunion Street (near Champs de Mars). He was released on 13 January after a ransom was paid.

On 11 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones and bottles in the direction of the Public Market. This one and other public buildings closed their doors due to the riots. Police forces intervened using tear gas to disperse the crowd. Demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe, a former convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti.

On 10 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the fourth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.
On 10 January 2024, in Port-de-Paix municipality, Nord-Ouest, police forces shot and killed a member of the Guepe Noire Gang during a clash in La Saline area. 1 fatality.

On 9 January 2024, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped more than 10 passengers from a bus and a tap-tap as they ambushed both vehicles on the National Road 1. Their whereabouts are unknown.

On 9 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 9 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, two individuals accused of being members of the 400 Mawozo Gang were killed and their burned bodies were found in the area of Moulin Sable (Gerardeau neighborhood). The residents have expressed that they are willing to take measures to prevent gangs from re-taking control over the area which has been pretty calm. According to the source the area is controlled by the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang). 2 fatalities.
On 8 January 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, unidentified armed groups clashed. There is no information on the circumstances of the clashes. Casualties unknown.
On 8 January 2024, in Bassin Bleu, Nord-Ouest, overnight, gang members decapitated a man and a woman as they returned from a business establishment that they owned. 2 fatalities.

On 8 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, members of a self-defense group from the Fort-Jacques area killed at least six members of the Vitelhomme gang, including a local leader of the gang in Metivier. Some firearms and materials belonging to the gangsters were seized and submitted to the police. Gunshots were also heard in areas like Vivy Mitchell and Freres Road. At least 6 fatalities.

On 8 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.
On 8 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, unidentified armed groups clashed in Torcelle. There is no information on the circumstances of the clashes. Casualties unknown.

On 7 January 2024, in the Artibonite department (coded to Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite), Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped a public transport vehicle with around 10 female and male passengers on board. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

Around 7 January 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, at least nine people were killed (methods unspecified) and their bodies were found partially burned at a dump site, in Delmas 19. Among the victims, there were seven men and two women, although only one of the men was identified. The scene was recorded and shared on social media. The perpetrators and the motivation for the attack are unknown. At least 9 fatalities.

On 7 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 6 January 2024, off the Coast of Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, unidentified gang members attacked a public transport canoe at the height of the Alpha Village, shooting and killing at least seven men and women, including several merchants. The canoe's destination was the coast of Gressier. The gangsters threw some corpses into the sea. An unknown number of passengers were injured. Several were kidnapped, including three women. Some of them were released. The whereabouts of the rest are unknown. At least 7 fatalities.
On 6 January 2024, off the Coast of Mariani, Ouest, gang members attacked a rowboat, killing five men and kidnapping three women who were on board. Their whereabouts are unknown. 5 fatalities.

On 5 January 2024, in La Coupe, Nord-Ouest, police forces shot and killed a member of the 305 Gang during an intervention near the Port-de-Paix River. One source described the deceased as the leader of the gang. Another individual was arrested. A firearm was seized. 1 fatality.

Around 5 January 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a police officer was killed and his body was found on the streets of the Bois Verna neighbourhood. The officer was thought to have been killed in unreported circumstances after leaving his home (assumed off-duty). Perpetrators and motivation unknown. 1 fatality.

On 4 January 2024, in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras gang kidnapped over a dozen of passengers from a bus traveling on the Route Nationale #1. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 3 January 2024, in Mariani, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, police forces clashed with unidentified gang members as they intervened to prevent the criminals from extorting drivers along the National Road 2. Casualties unknown.

On 2 January 2024, in Mariani, Ouest, armed gang members perpetrated an attack and set fire to a public transport vehicle which had been parked on the road and set up a roadblock. At least two people were killed and their bodies were found on the ground. At least 2 fatalities.

On 2 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals on motorcycles kidnapped two women when they were moving in a vehicle on their way home, in Tabarre 25. A boy who was travelling with the victims was not abducted. The kidnappers asked for a ransom of 600,000 USD as a condition for their liberation. The victims were released on 6 January as a result of a police intervention. A kidnapper was arrested.

On 2 January 2024, in Mariani, Ouest, police forces clashed with unidentified gang members as they intervened to prevent the criminals from extorting drivers along the National Road 2. Casualties unknown.

On 1 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, armed men attacked the premises of the company E-Power (Nanraguette/Drouillard neighborhood). At least one employee was injured. At least 1 injured.

On 1 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, citizens held a march towards the Champs-de-Mars Avenue, next to the National Palace, against Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, and calling for his departure. Police forces intervened using tear gas. No one was arrested or injured. The mobilization was held on the occasion of the 220th anniversary of the political independence of Haiti. There were reports of barricades with burning tires on the road in Christophe Avenue and Saint Geraud bridge.

Around 31 December 2023 (between 30 December - 1 January), in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, gang members killed a woman on the Rails Route (methods unknown). The victim was described as the niece of a journalist who got struck on the mentioned road (likely during the attack). No further details were mentioned. 1 fatality.

On 29 December 2023, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang attacked a bus transporting passengers, wounding at least five of them. The police intervened to make the gangsters retreat and a clash ensured, while some passengers had to run to nearby plantations to seek refuge. The wounded were taken to the hospital to receive care. At least 5 injured.

On 28 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, public employees of the National Solid Waste Management Service (SNGRS) held a demonstration at the Petite Place Cazeau square to demand higher wages. They set up barricades of burning tires on the road.

On 27 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, activists demonstrated and erected barricades of burning tires near the Ministry of Planning. There is no information on the motives of the demonstration.
On 27 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members in Carrefour Feuilles and La Saline. Casualties unknown.

On 26 December 2023, in the Ouest department (coded to Port-au-Prince - Delmas), Ouest, members of the Belair Gang, by order of their leader, killed another gangster and mutilated the body, as shown in a video. The killing responded to inter-gang fights. 1 fatality.

On 26 December 2023, around Port-de-Paix commune, Nord-Ouest, police forces shot and killed two gang members and injured three others during a clash between the 'Deye Letan' area, Amiral Kilick Street, and La Saline zone. The gangsters were described as members of the Ti Bwa Gang and the Zone 4 Gang. 2 fatalities, 3 injured.

On 26 December 2023, between Port-au-Prince - Gressier and Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, gang members killed at least five young men (methods unspecified) on the road leading to Ti Sous village (in the Carrefour commune). A report indicates that they were accused of being police informants. At least 5 fatalities.

On 25 December 2023, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, unidentified gang members killed four members of a family, including two girls (methods unspecified), and kidnapped four others during an attack. Their whereabouts are unknown. 4 fatalities.

On 24 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, overnight, an unknown number of armed individuals shot and killed a former deputy at his residence, in the Mahotiere 75 neighborhood, where the body was found on 25 December. The victim was described as a former member of the Socialist Action Movement and former head of the Vehicle Insurance Office (OAVCT). The house was vandalized. Perpetrators and motivation for the attack are unknown. 1 fatality.
On 23 December 2023, in Belladere, Centre, a customs agent shot and killed a driver for unknown reasons. No further details were mentioned. 1 fatality.
On 23 December 2023, in Bon Repos, Ouest, in the morning, unidentified gang members attacked a group of military officers, killing one and injuring another one. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

Around 23 December 2023 (between 22 - 23 December), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members near the Port Terminal, in the La Saline neighborhood. Two firearms and a vehicle were seized. Casualties unknown.

On 23 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, police forces shot and killed three siblings, one of them being a minor, after having arrested them during a police patrol. The attack was described as a case of summary executions. 3 fatalities.

On 21 December 2023, around Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, members of the Vitelhomme Gang (Kraze Barye Gang) and 400 Mawozo Gang clashed between Croix-des-Bouquets and Tabarre commune. Other clashes were recorded simultaneously in Petionville (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 21 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, members of the Vitelhomme Gang (Kraze Barye Gang) and 400 Mawozo Gang clashed in Pernier neighborhood. Other clashes were recorded simultaneously around Corix-des-Bouquets and Tabarre (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 20 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, public employees of the National Solid Waste Service (SNGRS) held a demonstration in front of the institution's facilities in Petite Place Cazeau demanding higher wages. They set up barricades of burning tires.

On 19 December 2023, in Liancourt, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang opened fire on a convoy of trucks transporting bags of charcoal from the Dominican Republic, killing at least five people on board, including a driver. Several others were injured. The convoy was guarded by a police armored vehicle, although no interaction between the officers and the gangsters was mentioned. One source stated that the convoy was integrated by public transport vehicles, although this was not confirmed by other media. Members of the Jean-Denis self-defense group confronted the gangsters (coded separately) and took the wounded civilians to hospital. At least 5 fatalities, several injured.

On 19 December 2023, in Liancourt, Artibonite, members of the Jean-Denis self-defense group clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang after these had attacked some vehicles and killed several civilians in the area (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 19 December 2023, in Montrouis, Artibonite, armed residents from the commune clashed over a land dispute. Three people were killed and six got injured by the bullets. 3 fatalities, 6 injured.

On 19 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a resident in the Canape-Vert neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances and the perpetrators, although the latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The whereabouts of the victim are unknown.

On 19 December 2023, in Ganthier, Ouest, police forces, together with members of a self-defense group, clashed with the 400 Mawozo Gang as they tried to expel the criminals from the commune. The gangsters had attacked residents and had engaged in armed clashes with police forces since 17 December (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 18 December 2023, in Balan, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang killed two men as they attacked the village. Later that day, another civilian was killed in the nearby 'Lot Bo Twou' area. At least three houses were set on fire. The attacks took place in the margin of a clash (coded separately). Between 17 and 18 December, at least five civilians were killed, six were injured, and several houses were set on fire as a result of the 400 Mawozo Gang attacks in the Ganthier commune. Some residents fled the area. 5 fatalities split across two events. At least 3 fatalities, several injured.
On 17 December 2023, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang attacked a public transport vehicle, killing the driver and a passenger. 2 fatalities.

On 17 December 2023, in Gonaives, Artibonite, overnight, gang members on a motorcycle shot and killed a young man on the street. His body was found in the early morning of 18 December (drive-by). 1 fatality.

On 17 December 2023, in Ganthier, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang attacked a police station and clashed with police officers as they launched a gang offensive against the commune. A woman and her baby were killed and their bodies were burned. The following day, gangs attacked the Balan village, resulting in 3 fatalities (coded separately). Between 17 and 18 December, at least five civilians were killed, six were injured, and several houses were set on fire as a result of the 400 Mawozo Gang attacks in the Ganthier commune. Some residents fled the area. 5 fatalities split across two events. At least 2 fatalities, several injured.

On 15 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a father who was traveling with his four children, who the kidnappers left in the car on the Christophe Avenue. There is no information on the perpetrators and circumstances of the kidnapping, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 15 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, a journalist was kidnapped on Delmas Road. The kidnappers requested a ransom of several hundreds of thousands of US dollars in exchange for his release. The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

On 14 December 2023, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, a group of Haitian nationals forced the barrier of the Haitian-Dominican border, broke the chains, padlocks, and a barrier portion, and threw it into the Massacre River. Some sources described the rioters as Haitian citizens living in the Dominican Republic while others identified them as Haitian truck drivers. Polifront border agents were present, although no intervention on their side was mentioned. The rioters' action aimed at opposing the closure of the border by the Dominican authorities in September (coded separately). Dominican security forces closed the border some hours later.

On 14 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, in the morning, gang members shot and injured a police officer near the National Police Academy, on the Freres Road. As other policemen intervened in response to the shooting, a gang member was shot and injured. A motorcycle was seized. 2 injured.

On 13 December 2023, near Pont Sonde, Artibonite, overnight, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang shot and killed at least two people (an elderly man and an elderly woman) as they perpetrated an attack at the height of Moreau Paye area. An unknown number of civilians were kidnapped and several houses were looted. Their whereabouts are unknown. At least 2 fatalities.

On 13 December 2023, Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unknown number of people were kidnapped in Bolosse. Although there is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the kidnapping, latest reports suggests that most abductions are gang-related. The victim(s)' whereabouts are unknown.

On 13 December 2023, in Mariani, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, police forces clashed with gang members as they carried out an anti-gang operation to expel the criminals from the commune. Several gangsters were killed. Gunshots were heard throughout the day. Several firearms were seized. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 13 December 2023, in the commune of Croix Des Bouquets (coded to Sibert), Ouest, an unknown number of armed men kidnapped the former mayor of Cite Soleil at his residence. Kidnappers asked for a ransom of 600,000 USD as a condition for his liberation. Some sources state that the abduction took place in Sibert while others say it was in Marin. His whereabouts are unknown.
Around 12 December 2023 (month of), in Tiburon, Sud, gang members killed a business man whom they had kidnapped. The victim was killed despite the payment of a ransom for his release. 1 fatality.

On 12 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, overnight, an unknown number of armed individuals shot and killed two men whose corpses were found next to a church on the Poupelard Avenue, on 13 December. One victim had been decapitated. Motivation and perpetrators are unknown. 2 fatalities.

On 12 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, at least 10 gang members beat up and shot and killed a critically wounded patient as they ambushed a convoy integrated by two ambulances belonging to Doctors Without Borders (MSF) near the Turgeau Emergency Centre (TEC) (in Turgeau neighbourhood). The gangsters fired shots into the air as they blocked the convoy's path, checked the interior of both ambulances, and forced one patient out of the vehicle before killing him on the street. The perpetrators fled the scene. On 14 December, MSF announced the suspension of its activity at TEC following the attack. There were no reports of health or aid workers being injured during the attack. 1 fatality.

On 12 December 2023, in Mariani, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they carried out an anti-gang operation to expel the criminals from the commune. During clashes, several civilians were shot and injured. Several houses used as refuge by the gangsters were burned and destroyed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
On 11 December 2023, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, police forces shot and injured three members of the Canaan Gang in the Daspinosse neighbourhood. A number of firearms were seized. 3 injured.
On 11 December 2023, in Port-Salut, Sud, the police clashed with members of the Bout Ba Gang that were in the city to attend a funeral. Casualties unknown.
On 10 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gang members kidnapped a man in Delmas 17 around a church where he had dropped his wife off. The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

Around 10 December 2023 (weekend of), in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu) attacked the Brooklyn neighbourhood as they tried to take control of the area. No further details were mentioned. Casualties unknown.

Around 10 December 2023 (weekend of), off the Coast of Leogane, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu) clashed with coast guards in a patrol. At least five gangsters were killed. Their bodies were found in La Gonave island. At least 5 fatalities.

On 9 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, a motorcycle driver was shot and killed while transporting merchandise in Pelerin 2. There is no information on who is behind the attack. 1 fatality.

Around 9 December 2023 (between 9 - 10 December), near Nan Sable, Sud, police forces shot and killed 17 members of the Ti Rach Gang (including one of its leaders and some women), injured a second gang leader, arrested three women affiliated to the organization, and released three hostages as part of a security operation in the 'Nan Woch' village (located in the 'Loby' 3rd communal section of Tiburon). The operation resulted in the dismantling of the gang. Several firearms were seized and makeshift accommodations used by the gangsters were set on fire and destroyed. A police officer got his foot broken. The wounded gang leader and another gangster were lynched by the population as they tried to run away. 19 fatalities, 2 injured.

On 8 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a woman as she met with them to submit a ransom asked for the liberation of a relative (journalist) who had been kidnapped on 27 November (coded separately). A ransom was asked for her release. Her whereabouts are unknown.

On 8 December 2023, in Mariani, Ouest, gang members ambushed and set fire to an armored police vehicle as they threw Molotov cocktails against it. The officers inside the vehicle managed to escape unharmed. There were no casualties.

On 8 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, the police clashed with armed individuals in Carrefour Drouillard. According to the report, the armed individuals threw stones at the police car. Casualties unknown.

On 7 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, in the morning, gang members kidnapped around 10 students from the Petit Seminaire Saint Martial School and the Sacre Coeur School when they were traveling in a school bus, in the Turgeau neighborhood. According to the driver, he was forced to exit the vehicle and submit the bus keys to the kidnappers, who fled the scene with the students on board. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.
On 7 December 2023, in Bon Repos, Ouest, police forces clashed with members of the Canaan Gang in Lizon and Ti Bob neighbourhoods. Casualties unknown.
On 7 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces clashed with an unknown number of armed individuals in the Carrefour-Feuilles neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

Around 6 December 2023 (as reported), in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, there were armed clashes between members of the Vitelhomme Gang and members of the 400 Mawozo Gang as part of an ongoing fight between these two gangs after some Vitelhomme gang members joined the 400 Mawozo (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 6 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, gang members shot and killed a former political candidate for the Saut d'Eau district at his residence, in the Vivy Mitchell neighbourhood. One version stated that the killing took place as he tried to resist an abduction attempt. Another version claimed that it happened as he tried to prevent a robbery by three armed men outside his house. 1 fatality.

Around 6 December 2023 (week of), in Mariani, Ouest, several gang members were killed (methods unknown) and their bodies were found on National Road 2. The victims were described as soldiers of the so-called 'Boutba' gang leader. The circumstances and perpetrators of these killings are unknown. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 6 December 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, police forces shot and killed two armed kidnappers as they intervened and thwarted an abduction attempt, in Delmas 19. During the incident, the victim, a woman who was forced to drive the car that was used for the kidnapping, was killed in the clash as well. 3 fatalities.
On 6 December 2023, in Mariani, Ouest, police forces shot and killed at least two gang members during anti-gang operations in the area. At least 2 fatalities.
On 5 December 2023, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals kidnapped a lawyer at his residence, in La Tremblay neighbourhood. The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

On 5 December 2023, in Frecineau, Artibonite, an unknown number of armed men in vehicles shot and killed a person and kidnapped four other civilians in the Village Mac Donald road. There is no further information on the perpetrators, although latest report suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown. 1 fatality.

On 5 December 2023, in Mariani, Ouest, gang members shot and killed a truck driver as they opened fire on his vehicle on the National Road 2, where the criminals had installed a toll booth. Another driver was injured during the shooting. According to police, the gangsters threw Molotov cocktails against vehicles circulating along the roadway. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

On 4 December 2023, in Gonaives, Artibonite, several tens of merchants, led by the Artibonite Drivers and Transporters Union, held a demonstration to demand the departure of the head of the municipal commission after the destruction of a local market, the so called 'Topa Market', by order of the local authorities the weekend prior. Demonstrators, who held tree branches, set up barricades of burning tires on several roads.

On 4 December 2023, in Les Anglais, Sud, members of the Ti Rach Gang killed, injured, and kidnapped an unknown number of civilians as they attacked the village. The victims' whereabouts are unknown. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 3 December 2023, in Trou-du-Nord, Nord-Est, overnight, citizens held a demonstration on the National Road 6 demanding the reopening of the Haitian-Dominican border. Demonstrators burned tires and parked vehicles on the road.

Around 3 December 2023 (weekend of), near Casale, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals kidnapped four civilians travelling in a mini-bus at the height of the Morne a Cabrit peak. Among the abducted, there was a former political candidate for the Boucan Carre commune. There is no further information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

Around 3 December 2023 (as reported), in Mariani, Ouest, police forces shot and killed several gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in the commune. The police recovered a heavy machine which had been stolen by the gangsters. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Around 1 December 2023 (between 29 November - 2 December), in Savien, Artibonite, an unknown number of people were kidnapped. These abductions were attributed to the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

On 1 December 2023, in Mariani, Ouest, members of the Bout Ba Gang clashed with police officers. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the clashes, the report indicates that at least one police officer was killed and another wounded. Two other BSAP officers were shown on video, but their physical state was unclear. At least 1 fatality. At least 1 injured.

On 30 November 2023, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, overnight, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang and its allies from the Palmiste Gang kidnapped around 15 parishioners at the Notre Dame de Fatima church. The victims were released on 3 December. No ransom was paid to the kidnappers.

On 30 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, there were armed clashes between members of the Vitelhomme Gang and members of the 400 Mawozo Gang in Torcelle. At least 12 Vitelhomme gangsters were killed. This clash is part of an ongoing fight between these two gangs after some Vitelhomme gang members joined the 400 Mawozo (coded separately). At least 12 fatalities.

On 30 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, residents held a demonstration in Laboule 12 to decry the killing of young man by a military officer the day before (coded separately). Demonstrators burned tires on the road.

On 30 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, a leader of the Vitelhomme gang (Kraze Barye) was shot and killed. There is no information on the perpetrators. The gang members led the Vitelhomme faction that operates in Penye 50 (Pernie), Furcy and Chateaublon areas. 1 fatality.

On 30 November 2023, in Mariani, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they carried out an anti-gang operation between Gressier and Carrefour communes. During clashes, a police officer was killed and another one was injured. The corpse of the deceased was desecrated by the gangsters, who recorded the scene on video. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

Around 29 November 2023 (as reported), in Lambert, Artibonite, the leader of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang shot a woman in her vagina as she refused to have sexual relations with him. She died in hospital. The victim was shot in front of her brother, who was a member of the Gran Grif Gang. The victim had been raped by the gang leader before (uncoded). Her affiliation was not clarified. 1 fatality.

On 29 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, a military officer killed a young man (methods unspecified) on the Boutiers Road (Turgeau neighbourhood, Port-au-Prince). No further details on the circumstances of the attack were mentioned. 1 fatality.

Around 29 November 2023 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, police forces shot and killed several gang members as they engaged in armed clashes during an anti-gang operation in Mariani near the National Route 2. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 28 November 2023, close to Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, a group of truckers at the Haitian-Dominican border, some of them masked and armed, led by a Haitian truckers union, and supported by traders, and custom agents, forced the border barriers, broke the locks, and opened the cross point, allowing free movement of trucks for a while. Journalists who tried to take pictures were physically aggressed. Soldiers from the Haitian and Dominican sides closed the border, although no interaction with the truckers was mentioned. The incident happened as the closure of the border in September persists. Casualties unknown.

On 28 November 2023, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, a mob of residents lynched and burned the corpse of a man whom they accused of being a thief. The victim was a suspected gang member. The attack was described as vigilante violence. 1 fatality.

On 28 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in Bas Delmas. Gunshots were heard across the area, as well as in La Saline and Aviation crossroad. Casualties unknown.

On 28 November 2023, in Mariani, Ouest, at least 15 bodies were burned on the National Road 2. The victims were deceased Grand-Ravine gangsters who had been killed by police forces during armed clashes the day before (coded separately). The people behind the burning of the bodies remain unknown, although this is likely to be a case of vigilante violence by mobs of residents.

On 28 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, students from the State University of Haiti (UEH) held a demonstration on the Christophe Avenue to demand the release of a colleague who was kidnapped around 27 November (coded separately). Burning barricades were erected in Nazon, on Oswald Durand street and St Geraud Bridge.

On 28 November 2023, near Port-au-Prince - Kenscoff, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped a doctor near his coffee farm, located at the Belot mountains. The abducted is the son of the GHESKIO health centre's owner. His family paid up to five ransoms. He was released on 9 March 2024. The doctor was tortured while in captivity (health state unknown). Casualties unknown.
On 28 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, armed individuals exchanged fire. There is no information on the circumstances of the gunshots. Casualties unknown.

On 28 November 2023, in Plaisance, Nord, a police officer was shot and injured while he was at a party (likely off-duty). He died on 5 December. The circumstances and perpetrators of the shooting are unknown. 1 fatality.

Around 27 November 2023 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a student from the State University of Haiti (UEH) on the Christophe Avenue, in the Turgeau neighbourhood. The victim was released on 1 December after the payment of a ransom. The amount was not clarified, although it is known that the abductors had demanded 600,000 USD as a condition for his liberation. They had also threatened to kill him if the ransom was not transferred.

On 27 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, an unknown number of armed men kidnapped a radio journalist, his wife, and son when they were on their way home, in Delmas 31. Their vehicle and belongings were taken by the kidnappers. On 8 December, the journalist was released as a woman relative met with the kidnappers and submitted a ransom. The relative was then, in turn, abducted while giving the ransom (coded separately). The journalist's wife and son had been released some days before.

On 27 November 2023, in Mariani, Ouest, police forces clashed with Grand-Ravine gang members, killing at least three. During the gunfire, at least three civilians travelling in a mini-bus were killed by the stray bullets. Other passengers and the driver were injured. The clash took place as the police intervened to expel the gangsters who had installed a toll both in the commune. As clashes continued along the day, at least 15 fatalities were counted among the gangsters. Their corpses were found burned the day after (coded separately). At least 18 fatalities, at least 6 injured.

On 26 November 2023, in Leogane, Ouest, overnight, an unknown number of gang members perpetrated an attack from the sea against the residents of the Ca-Ira neighbourhood. One civilian was physically aggressed (no further details were mentioned). The gangsters robbed at least one ship belonging to the 'Food for the Poor' NGO, a motorcycle, and other items from houses and shops. There were no fatalities.

On 26 November 2023, in Gonaives, Artibonite, overnight, a former leader of the extinct Artibonite Resistance Front was shot and injured on his foot. The circumstances around the shooting were not clarified and several versions were given. At least one source stated that he was shot by armed men during an altercation, while several others supported that it was the police who shot at him during an intervention at a night club. The wounded, who was arrested, was also described as a former leader of Les Revolutionnaires (a.k.a. Raboteau's Revolutionary Force). 1 injured.

On 26 November 2023, near Cavaillon, Sud, security forces, led by the Muscadin police commissioner, shot and killed a man driving a vehicle with 18 passengers on board, including two minors. The deceased was described as a member of the 400 Mawozo Gang. The killing was said to be an extrajudicial execution. 1 fatality.

Around 25 November 2023 (weekend of), in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, there were armed clashes between members of the Vitelhomme Gang and members of the 400 Mawozo Gang in Torcelle. The clashes in which at least twelve Vitelhomme gang members were killed occurred when some Vitelhomme gang members joined the 400 Mawozo. At least 12 fatalities.

On 25 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of the Grand-Ravine Gang shot and killed at least six civilians, injured several others, and kidnapped an unknown number of residents as they attacked the Carrefour-Feuilles neighbourhood. The corpses of the deceased were tortured and burned. The attack took place as a police armored vehicle left the area and residents who had fled their homes due to gang violence were returning after being encouraged to do so through social media. Following the attack, police forces intervened and clashed with the gangsters (coded separately). At least 6 fatalities, several injured.

Around 25 November 2023 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces clashed with members of the Grand-Ravine Gang in Carrefour-Feuilles as they intervened to expel them from the neighbourhood. Clashes took place after an attack by the Grand-Ravine Gang that left at least six civilians killed (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 24 November 2023, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, police forces engaged in armed clashes with an unknown number of gang members in the Madeline neighbourhood, shooting and killing one of them. The rest of gang members managed to flee the scene. A firearm was seized. The clash took place as police forces were called and intervened to expel gangsters who had attacked civilians in the area moments before (coded separately). 1 fatality.

On 23 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in different areas, such as Nazon, Sylvio Cator and Charlemagne B streets. The report indicates that the gunfire is a result of ongoing clashes between gangs that are present in those areas. Casualties unknown.

On 23 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 18, 20, 24, 26, and 28. The report indicates that the gunfire is a result of ongoing clashes between gangs that are present in those areas. Casualties unknown.

On 23 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a woman as she was the victim of a virtual scam that made her go to Port-au-Prince expecting to meet someone she had talked to through Facebook. Kidnappers asked for a ransom of more than 2 million gourdes as a condition for her release. Her whereabouts are unknown.

On 23 November 2023, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, overnight, gang members attacked and killed an unknown number of civilians on the so called 'SOS Road', on Madeline neighbourhood. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 22 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members attacked residents as they tried to take control of the Solino neighbourhood, shooting and injuring at least one civilian. The attack was attributed to the Belair Gang. Gunshots were heard across the neighbourhood. Many families left their homes and gunshots and the presence of armed men were reported in Solino and Nazon neighborhoods. At least 1 injured.

On 22 November 2023, in Mariani, Ouest, Grand-Ravine gang members perpetrated a collective kidnapping. It is unknown how many people were kidnapped and no further details were reported. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 22 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members kidnapped an unknown number of passengers from a bus downtown. They released the driver as well as the bus. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 22 November 2023, in Mariani, Ouest, police forces clashed with affiliates of the Grand-Ravine Gang as they intervened to expel the criminals from the areas that they had occupied after they attacked Mariani on 1 November (coded separately). The gangsters fled the area. Many families left their homes. Casualties unknown.

Around 21 November 2023 (as reported), near Port-au-Prince - Kenscoff, Ouest, an unspecified number of people were abducted in the Pelerin 5 neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the kidnapping. However, latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related.

On 21 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, members of the G-9 Gang coalition killed the recently self-proclaimed as new leader of the Belekou Gang. The killing was perpetrated by the so called 'Bendjy', who proclaimed himself as the new Belekou Gang leader. The motivation for the attack were accusations against the deceased of being involved in the death of the Belekou Gang former leader, who died on 12 November under unclarified circumstances (coded separately). 1 fatality.

On 20 November 2023, in Gonaives, Artibonite, several people were kidnapped by members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang while they were inside the Notre-Dame de Fatima church participating in a night vigil. The whereabouts of the victims are unknown.

On 20 November 2023, in Bassin Bleu, Nord-Ouest, members of the gang operating in Ti Bwadom kidnapped 15 passengers from a bus heading towards Port-de-Paix after seizing all their possessions. They requested a ransom of 500.000 gourdes in exchange for their release. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.
On 19 November 2023, in Croix-des-Bouquets commune, Ouest, there were armed clashes on Route 9. There is no information on the circumstances or actors involved in the clashes. Casualties unknown.

On 19 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, rival gang members clashed in La Saline, Solino, Wharf Jeremie, Fort National, Delmas 4, and Belair neighbourhoods. During clashes in Solino, a police officer was shot and killed, while another officer was injured. At least two people were killed by stray bullets. An unknown number were injured. The gangsters set fire to houses and vehicles. Gunshots were heard across the neighbourhoods. Several sources stated the involvement of G-Pep La Gang affiliates (like the Belair Gang), while others pointed at the Micanord Gang against the Base Krache Dife Gang. At least 3 fatalities, several injured.
On 19 November 2023, in Marin, Ouest, there were armed clashes. There is no information on the circumstances or actors involved in the clashes. Casualties unknown.
On 19 November 2023, in Sibert, Ouest there were armed clashes. There is no information on the circumstances or actors involved in the clashes. Casualties unknown.

On 19 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unknown number of gang members in a vehicle opened fire on a police patrol on La Reunion Street (drive-by). A clash erupted, as the officers returned fire and chased them. The shooters tried to run away, although the police was able to seize a riffle and their vehicle. Casualties unknown.

On 18 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, an unspecified number of people were abducted in the Thomassin neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the kidnapping. However, latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related.

On 17 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, for the fifth consecutive day, G-9 gang members clashed with the G-Pep La Gang coalition as they fought to replace the Belekou Gang leader (and G-9 affiliate), who used to control the area and died on 12 November (coded separately). An unknown number of civilians were killed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 17 November 2023, in Thomazeau, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo gang killed at least five people and injured at least two as they attacked and set fire to several houses in Durand and Letang neighbourhoods. The home of a former deputy was burned. At least 5 fatalities, at least 2 injured.

On 16 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, the Chien Mechant Gang clashed with gangsters from Croix des Mission and Brooklyn (a.k.a Ti Gabriel Gang), as they fought to replace the Belekou Gang leader (and G-9 Gang affiliate), who died on 12 November (coded separately). An unknown number of civilians were hit by the bullets in Simon Pele neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

On 16 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, for the fourth consecutive day, G-9 gang members clashed with the G-Pep La Gang coalition and the Ti Gabriel Gang as they fought to replace the Belekou Gang leader (and G-9 affiliate), who used to control the area and died on 12 November (coded separately). An unknown number of civilians and gangsters were killed, including a woman who was accused of being a gang informant. She was decapitated by Ti Gabriel affiliates. Others were injured. Between 13 and 16 November, ReliefWeb reported the burning of houses, the rape of women, and at least 166 fatalities amidst clashes. At least 166 fatalities split across six clashes reported in Cite-Soleil between 13 and 16 November.

On 16 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, members of two gangs, both allies of the G-9 Gang coalition, engaged in armed clashes in the Belekou and Boston neighbourhoods as they fought to replace the Belekou Gang leader (and G-9 affiliate), who used to control the area and died on 12 November (coded separately). Between 13 and 16 November, ReliefWeb reported the burning of houses, the rape of women, and at least 166 fatalities amidst clashes. At least 166 fatalities split across six clashes reported in Cite-Soleil between 13 and 16 November.

On 16 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, overnight, gang members attacked residents in the commune, killing an unknown number of civilians. The attack was described as a reprisal for a police intervention that resulted in the killing of some gangsters earlier that day (coded separately). Unspecified casualties coded as 3.

On 16 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, police forces killed an unknown number of gang members as they intervened to expel the criminals who had engaged in armed clashes with rival gangsters earlier that day (coded separately). In reprisal to the police intervention, the gangsters attacked residents in the area overnight (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
Around 15 November 2023 (as reported), in Gonaives, Artibonite, gang members on a motorcycle shot and killed a young man on the street. (drive-by). 1 fatality.

On 15 November 2023, in Fonds Baptiste, Arcahaie, armed men coming from Doco, Robert, and other nearby villages attacked members of the Fonds Baptiste Communal Militia as they perpetrated an attack to regain control of dispossessed lands. Clashes took place in the frame of a long-term land conflict. During clashes, more than 60 houses and an unknown number of bodies were set on fire. Crops were destroyed and more than 200 cattle heads were slaughtered. According to residents, at least 50 people were killed by gunshots or with machetes. The authorities counted at least 27. At least 27 fatalities.

On 15 November 2023, near Saint-Marc, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang shot and killed a truck driver and injured a person accompanying him in Moreau area. Motivation unknown. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

On 15 November 2023, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, the G-9 gang clashed with the G-Pep La Gang coalition and the Ti Gabriel Gang. As part of the offensive, Ti Gabriel gangsters set fire to houses and fired shots near La Fontaine Hospital, hitting the building and preventing hundreds of patients (including children) from leaving the health centre. Police forces intervened with armoured trucks, clashed with the gangsters, and evacuated civilians from the hospital, which ceased operations until further notice. An unknown number of civilians and gangsters were killed and injured. Some residents fled their homes. Clashes erupted as the gang members fought to replace the Belekou Gang leader (and G-9 affiliate), who used to control the area and died on 12 November (coded separately).
